text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in Russian newspapers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Moscow authorities approved a new list of tough measures for the owners of private cars to improve ecology in the capital.
- Anatoly Chubais, one of two deputy prime ministers, announced on Tuesday that the government plans no big issues of T-bills and OFZs.
- Advertisments for alcohol may reappear on Russia's TV screens according to the new legislation to be discussed in parliament on May 20.
- The top man in Russian hockey must have been in somebody's way and was killed.
- The government is ready with measures to restructure natural monopolies and change the tax system.
- Four representatives of the LUKoil company, which owns 41 percent of Izvestia's stock, were elected on Tuesday to the directors' board of Russia'a leading independent daily.
- The government calls on commercial banks to focus on industry.
- Russia and China may announce a strategic partnership.

- In the current situation cutting budget expenditures looks like cutting off a hand drained of blood by a tourniquet, the paper says, referring to planned government measures to improve economic reforms.

- The government is trying to turn Russia into a third world country where one or two percent of the population is very rich while the majority is very poor, says the paper referring to a new draft of the Tax Code which does not foresee any cuts in income taxes for ordinary people.
